pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 206, 332, 221]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 247, 590, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 312, 386, 327]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 342, 890, 415]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 430, 890, 460]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 460, 888, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 489, 555, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 518, 764, 578]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer. Any rough working should be done in this booklet. Electronic calculators may be used. Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 858, 90]]<|/det|>
A pendulum is set in motion and timed. The time measured for 20 complete swings is 30 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 597, 120]]<|/det|>
What is the time for one complete swing of the pendulum?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 695, 147]]<|/det|>
**A** 0.67 s **B** 0.75 s **C** 1.5 s **D** 3.0 s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 176, 96, 195]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 176, 570, 193]]<|/det|>
The diagrams are distance-time graphs for four bodies.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 206, 520, 223]]<|/det|>
Which body is moving with an increasing speed?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 234, 790, 585]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 615, 96, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 615, 919, 647]]<|/det|>
A runner runs 300 m at an average speed of 3.0 m/s. She then runs another 300 m at an average speed of 6.0 m/s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 660, 598, 676]]<|/det|>
What is her average speed for the total distance of 600 m?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 688, 720, 705]]<|/det|>
**A** 2.0 m/s **B** 4.0 m/s **C** 4.5 m/s **D** 8.0 m/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 733, 96, 751]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 733, 451, 750]]<|/det|>
Which quantity is measured in newtons?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 762, 214, 778]]<|/det|>
**A** energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 789, 201, 804]]<|/det|>
**B** mass

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 815, 212, 830]]<|/det|>
**C** weight

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 841, 196, 856]]<|/det|>
**D** work

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 847, 90]]<|/det|>
Four identical steel blocks are placed on a balance. The reading on the balance is 220 N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 422, 120]]<|/det|>
What is the mass of one steel block?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 700, 148]]<|/det|>
**A** 5.5kg **B** 22kg **C** 55kg **D** 88kg

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 176, 96, 195]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 176, 591, 193]]<|/det|>
A liquid has a volume of \(0.040 \text{m}^3\) and a mass of \(30 000 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 206, 388, 223]]<|/det|>
What is the density of the liquid?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 234, 753, 252]]<|/det|>
**A** \(0.075 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\) **B** \(7.5 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\) **C** \(750 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\) **D** \(7500 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 279, 96, 298]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 279, 904, 297]]<|/det|>
The unstretched lengths and extension-load graphs are shown for each of four different springs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 310, 732, 327]]<|/det|>
Which spring is the longest when a load of 5.0 N is hung from each spring?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 337, 887, 878]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 380, 90]]<|/det|>
A car moves along a level road.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 645, 120]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows all of the horizontal forces acting on the car.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 131, 825, 225]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 355, 259]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 272, 358, 288]]<|/det|>
A The car is slowing down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 298, 350, 313]]<|/det|>
B The car is speeding up.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 324, 470, 339]]<|/det|>
C The car is moving at a constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 350, 400, 365]]<|/det|>
D The car is moving backwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 394, 96, 412]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 394, 697, 410]]<|/det|>
Which force and distance produce the smallest moment about a pivot?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 422, 675, 438]]<|/det|>
A a 6.0N force at a perpendicular distance of 4.0m from the pivot

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 448, 675, 464]]<|/det|>
B a 7.0N force at a perpendicular distance of 6.0m from the pivot

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 475, 670, 490]]<|/det|>
C a 10N force at a perpendicular distance of 4.0m from the pivot

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 501, 670, 516]]<|/det|>
D a 12N force at a perpendicular distance of 3.0m from the pivot

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 545, 107, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 545, 720, 561]]<|/det|>
Which device is designed to convert chemical energy into kinetic energy?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 573, 300, 588]]<|/det|>
A an a.c. generator

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 600, 352, 615]]<|/det|>
B a battery-powered torch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 626, 259, 641]]<|/det|>
C a car engine

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 652, 382, 667]]<|/det|>
D a wind-up mechanical clock

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 696, 109, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 696, 308, 712]]<|/det|>
A man climbs a ladder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 725, 737, 741]]<|/det|>
Which two quantities can be used to calculate the useful power of the man?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 753, 531, 768]]<|/det|>
A the weight of the man and the time taken only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 780, 638, 795]]<|/det|>
B the weight of the man and the vertical distance moved only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 806, 567, 821]]<|/det|>
C the work done by the man and the time taken only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 832, 674, 847]]<|/det|>
D the work done by the man and the vertical distance moved only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 760, 90]]<|/det|>
A manometer is used to measure the pressure of gas inside a metal container.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[290, 100, 705, 318]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 330, 465, 346]]<|/det|>
What is the pressure inside the container?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 358, 135, 376]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 358, 435, 375]]<|/det|>
equal to the atmospheric pressure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 384, 468, 401]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 383, 470, 400]]<|/det|>
greater than the atmospheric pressure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 410, 620, 427]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 409, 620, 426]]<|/det|>
less than the atmospheric pressure but greater than zero

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 437, 193, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 437, 193, 452]]<|/det|>
zero

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 481, 107, 498]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 481, 635, 498]]<|/det|>
A manometer is used to measure the pressure of a gas supply.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 507, 715, 666]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 676, 519, 693]]<|/det|>
Which change gives a greater value of height \(h?\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 704, 136, 723]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 705, 359, 721]]<|/det|>
using a less dense liquid

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 731, 368, 747]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 730, 368, 747]]<|/det|>
using a more dense liquid

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 757, 336, 774]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 757, 335, 773]]<|/det|>
using a narrower tube

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 783, 306, 800]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 783, 306, 800]]<|/det|>
using a wider tube

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 109, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|> During evaporation of a liquid, the more energetic molecules escape. The temperature of the remaining liquid changes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 918, 135]]<|/det|> Which row identifies where these molecules escape from and describes the temperature change? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 147, 591, 292]]<|/det|>
molecules escape from thetemperature of remaining liquid
Abody of the liquiddecreases
Bbody of the liquidincreases
Csurface of the liquiddecreases
Dsurface of the liquidincreases
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 320, 109, 338]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 320, 675, 338]]<|/det|> Diagram 1 shows apparatus being used to observe smoke particles. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 588, 368]]<|/det|> Diagram 2 shows how a smoke particle moves randomly. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 377, 887, 640]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 653, 490, 670]]<|/det|> Why do the smoke particles move randomly? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 681, 396, 698]]<|/det|> A They are hit by air molecules. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 708, 393, 724]]<|/det|> B They are less dense than air. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 734, 484, 751]]<|/det|> C They are moved by convection currents. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 761, 415, 777]]<|/det|> D They gain energy from the light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 106]]<|/det|> The distance between two electricity pylons is \(60 \text{m}\). An engineer fits a cable of length \(62 \text{m}\) between the pylons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 905, 135]]<|/det|> Why does the engineer choose a cable that is longer than the distance between the two pylons? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 146, 571, 163]]<|/det|> **A** to allow for contraction of the cable in cold weather <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 172, 607, 189]]<|/det|> **B** to create a slope in the cable for electrons to flow down <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 199, 515, 215]]<|/det|> **C** to keep the current low and the voltage high <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 224, 505, 240]]<|/det|> **D** to reduce magnetic fields around the cable <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 269, 107, 287]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 269, 920, 301]]<|/det|> Some ice is slowly heated and its temperature is measured. A graph is plotted of temperature against time. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 311, 777, 466]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 481, 895, 498]]<|/det|> Which row describes what happens to the thermal energy and to the temperature in section X? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 510, 532, 638]]<|/det|>
thermal energytemperature of ice
Agained by icerises
Bgained by icestays the same
Cnot gained by icerises
Dnot gained by icestays the same

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 109, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Some of the Sun's radiation passes through a prism. The diagram shows the spectrum of the radiation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 623, 135]]<|/det|>
Which point on the screen does the infra-red radiation reach?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 145, 841, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 400, 107, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 400, 786, 419]]<|/det|>
On a cold day, a shiny metal rod feels colder to the touch than a black plastic rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 431, 477, 448]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains this observation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 460, 770, 477]]<|/det|>
A The metal rod is a better absorber of infra-red radiation than the plastic rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 486, 675, 503]]<|/det|>
B The metal rod is a better thermal conductor than the plastic rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 513, 772, 530]]<|/det|>
C The metal rod is a worse absorber of infra-red radiation than the plastic rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 540, 678, 556]]<|/det|>
D The metal rod is a worse thermal conductor than the plastic rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 583, 107, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 583, 657, 600]]<|/det|>
A boat moves up and down repeatedly as a water wave passes it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 612, 855, 630]]<|/det|>
Which name is given to the number of up-and-down movements of the boat per unit time?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 641, 237, 655]]<|/det|>
A amplitude

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 667, 237, 682]]<|/det|>
B frequency

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 693, 207, 707]]<|/det|>
C speed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 718, 250, 733]]<|/det|>
D wavelength

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>21</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
Plane water waves travel from a shallow region into a deeper region. They travel more quickly in the deeper water.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 115, 667, 231]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 243, 618, 260]]<|/det|>
Which diagram shows the wave pattern in the deeper water?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 271, 920, 390]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 412, 107, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>22</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 413, 546, 431]]<|/det|>
A parallel beam of light is incident on a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 636, 461]]<|/det|>
Which diagram shows how the beam is reflected by the mirror?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 472, 868, 801]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>23</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a parallel, cylindrical light beam of diameter \(d\) incident on a thin converging lens. A screen is placed a distance equal to two focal lengths \(2f\) from the lens.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[265, 115, 730, 300]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 313, 693, 332]]<|/det|>
Which diagram shows the size of the spot of light seen on the screen?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 341, 790, 444]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 472, 107, 490]]<|/det|>
<label>24</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 472, 919, 505]]<|/det|>
Different parts of the electromagnetic spectrum are used for different purposes. Below are four statements about parts of the spectrum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 518, 762, 536]]<|/det|>
statement 1: Infra-red waves are used in television remote controllers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 545, 918, 562]]<|/det|>
statement 2: Radio waves are used to transmit television pictures from satellites to Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 571, 675, 588]]<|/det|>
statement 3: Ultraviolet waves are used for intruder alarms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 597, 591, 613]]<|/det|>
statement 4: X-rays are used for security checks.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 626, 371, 643]]<|/det|>
Which statements are correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 654, 133, 672]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 654, 195, 672]]<|/det|>
1 and 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 654, 390, 672]]<|/det|>
B 1 and 4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 654, 550, 672]]<|/det|>
C 2 and 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 654, 718, 672]]<|/det|>
D 3 and 4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 548, 90]]<|/det|> A woman hears the first note produced by a clarinet. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 103, 675, 120]]<|/det|> She then hears a second note that has a higher pitch and is quieter. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 133, 708, 150]]<|/det|> Which row compares the frequency and the amplitude of the two notes? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 161, 551, 288]]<|/det|>
first notesecond note
Ahigher frequencylarger amplitude
Bhigher frequencysmaller amplitude
Clower frequencylarger amplitude
Dlower frequencysmaller amplitude
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 316, 107, 335]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 317, 636, 335]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a bar magnet and four plotting compasses. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 348, 750, 365]]<|/det|> Which compass shows the direction of the magnetic field due to the magnet? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 375, 700, 535]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 565, 107, 583]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 565, 784, 583]]<|/det|> Iron is used for the core of a transformer and steel is used to make a bar magnet. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 596, 593, 613]]<|/det|> Which statement explains these uses of iron and of steel? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 625, 680, 642]]<|/det|> **A** Iron is a magnetic material and steel is a non-magnetic material. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 651, 825, 668]]<|/det|> **B** Iron is a permanent magnetic material and steel is a temporary magnetic material. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 677, 825, 694]]<|/det|> **C** Iron is a temporary magnetic material and steel is a permanent magnetic material. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 704, 680, 720]]<|/det|> **D** Iron is a non-magnetic material and steel is a magnetic material.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 816, 90]]<|/det|> A negatively charged plastic rod P is placed above a positively charged plastic rod Q. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[380, 102, 617, 177]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 189, 720, 206]]<|/det|> What are the directions of the electrostatic forces on rod P and on rod Q? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 219, 540, 364]]<|/det|>
electrostatic force on rod Pelectrostatic force on rod Q
Adownwardsdownwards
Bdownwardsupwards
Cupwardsdownwards
Dupwardsupwards
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 392, 107, 409]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 392, 530, 409]]<|/det|> The diagrams show the scales of three ammeters. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 419, 920, 583]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 594, 529, 611]]<|/det|> Which ammeters show the same current reading? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 623, 310, 640]]<|/det|> **A** all three ammeters <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 650, 413, 666]]<|/det|> **B** ammeter 1 and ammeter 2 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 676, 413, 692]]<|/det|> **C** ammeter 1 and ammeter 3 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 702, 413, 718]]<|/det|> **D** ammeter 2 and ammeter 3 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 746, 107, 765]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 746, 823, 763]]<|/det|> The resistance of a component in a circuit is found using an ammeter and a voltmeter. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 777, 547, 793]]<|/det|> How are the ammeter and the voltmeter connected? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 805, 628, 821]]<|/det|> **A** the voltmeter and ammeter in parallel with the component <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 832, 618, 848]]<|/det|> **B** the voltmeter and ammeter in series with the component <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 859, 898, 875]]<|/det|> **C** the voltmeter in parallel with the component and the ammeter in series with the component <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 885, 898, 901]]<|/det|> **D** the voltmeter in series with the component and the ammeter in parallel with the component

The diagram shows a circuit with a power supply and four components.
